title: Week 4: January 19–25 - Genesis 3–4; Moses 4–5
script:
Welcome to the Come Follow Me Podcast by Gospel Study App. Imagine for a moment that you’re standing at the edge of the Garden of Eden, watching Adam and Eve take their first steps into a world unknown. The beauty of the garden is behind them—lush trees, perfect peace, and the presence of God Himself. Ahead lies a wilderness of thorns, toil, and uncertainty. What must they have felt in that moment? Were they afraid? Did they regret their choice? Or did they sense, even faintly, that this difficult path was the very one that would lead them—and all of us—back to God in a deeper, more glorious way? Today, as we dive into Genesis 3–4 and Moses 4–5, we’re going to explore the story of the Fall, not as a tragedy, but as a necessary step in God’s plan, a doorway to growth, redemption, and joy.

Let’s start by stepping into the garden with Adam and Eve. In Genesis 3:1–7, we read how the serpent tempted Eve, and she partook of the forbidden fruit, followed by Adam. The consequences were immediate and heavy. The Lord said to Eve in Genesis 3:16, “I will greatly multiply thy sorrow and thy conception; in sorrow thou shalt bring forth children; and thy desire shall be to thy husband, and he shall rule over thee.” To Adam, in verse 17, He said, “Cursed is the ground for thy sake; in sorrow shalt thou eat of it all the days of thy life.” Pain, sorrow, toil, and separation from God’s presence—these were the results of the Fall. But let’s pause to let that resonate. Why would a loving Heavenly Father allow such consequences? Could there be a purpose behind this pain?

As we turn to the Book of Moses, restored through the Prophet Joseph Smith, we gain a clearer view. In Moses 4:22–25, the Lord explains these same consequences, but the tone shifts as we move to Moses 5. Here, we see Adam and Eve beginning to understand. After they had been driven out of the garden, they called upon the Lord. In Moses 5:4–5, we read, “And Adam and Eve, his wife, called upon the name of the Lord, and they heard the voice of the Lord from the way toward the Garden of Eden, speaking unto them, and they saw him not; for they were shut out from his presence. And he gave unto them commandments, that they should worship the Lord their God, and should offer the firstlings of their flocks, for an offering unto the Lord.” Even in their separation, God did not abandon them. He spoke to them. He gave them commandments. And through an angel, He revealed the purpose of their sacrifices.

This brings us to a beautiful moment in Moses 5:10–11, where Adam and Eve express their newfound understanding. Adam says, “Blessed be the name of God, for because of my transgression my eyes are opened, and in this life I shall have joy, and again in the flesh I shall see God.” Eve echoes this in verse 11, saying, “Were it not for our transgression we never should have had seed, and never should have known good and evil, and the joy of our redemption, and the eternal life which God giveth unto all the obedient.” Take a quiet moment to reflect on their words. They’re not mourning their loss—they’re rejoicing in what they’ve gained. The Fall opened their eyes to joy, to family, to the knowledge of good and evil, and most importantly, to the redemption offered through Jesus Christ.

This truth leads us to a broader perspective on God’s plan. Why was the Fall necessary? Let’s look to Lehi’s teachings in 2 Nephi 2:22–23 for insight. He explains, “And now, behold, if Adam had not transgressed he would not have fallen, but he would have remained in the Garden of Eden. And all things which were created must have remained in the same state in which they were after they were created; and they must have remained forever, and had no end. And they would have had no children; wherefore they would have remained in a state of innocence, having no joy, for they knew no misery; doing no good, for they knew no sin.” Without the Fall, there would be no progress, no growth, no family, no purpose. Opposition, as Lehi teaches in 2 Nephi 2:11, is essential: “For it must needs be, that there is an opposition in all things.” Reflect on that for a second. How has opposition in your own life helped you grow closer to God?

Building on that vision, let’s consider how the Fall ties directly to the hope and redemption offered through Jesus Christ. In Moses 5:6–8, an angel explains to Adam the meaning of sacrifice, saying, “This thing is a similitude of the sacrifice of the Only Begotten of the Father, which is full of grace and truth. Wherefore, thou shalt do all that thou doest in the name of the Son, and thou shalt repent and call upon God in the name of the Son forevermore.” Every sacrifice Adam and Eve offered pointed to the ultimate sacrifice of Jesus Christ, who would overcome the effects of the Fall—sin and death—for all of us. This is why Eve could say she was glad. The Fall brought challenges, but it also brought the need for a Savior, and through Him, eternal life.

Notice how this pattern continues in our own lives. Think about the challenges you face because of the fallen world—whether it’s physical pain, emotional struggles, or the daily battle against temptation. How do these difficulties mirror what Adam and Eve experienced? Now consider how the Savior’s Atonement lifts you out of those struggles. In Moses 5:15, we read, “And as many as believed in the Son, and repented of their sins, should be saved; and as many as believed not and repented not, should be damned.” The choice is ours, just as it was for Adam and Eve’s children. Will we turn to the Savior and find redemption, or will we, like Cain in Moses 5:16–26, reject the Lord’s counsel and follow our own way?

This brings us to another vital principle from these chapters: agency. In Moses 4:1–4, we learn about the premortal council where Satan sought to destroy our agency, saying, “I will redeem all mankind, that one soul shall not be lost, and surely I will do it; wherefore give me thine honor.” But Heavenly Father’s plan preserved our right to choose, even if it meant we’d face opposition. Jesus Christ stepped forward to uphold that plan, ensuring we could grow through our choices. Ponder that for a moment. How does knowing that your agency was defended by the Savior Himself change the way you view your daily decisions?

As we draw this exploration to a close, let’s reflect on what Adam and Eve teach us. Their story isn’t just about a garden lost; it’s about a path gained—a path of growth through opposition, of hope through redemption, and of returning to God through the Savior’s Atonement. Their journey shows us that even in a fallen world, we can find joy, just as they did. So, as you go through this week, I invite you to take a moment each day to ponder one effect of the Fall in your life—maybe a challenge or a struggle—and then consider how the Savior’s Atonement helps you overcome it. Write down your thoughts or share them with a loved one. Let that reflection draw you closer to Him who makes all things possible. Until we meet again, may you feel the hope and joy of this glorious plan.
